Encapsulating MPLS in UDP
Abstract
contents.ja: 抽象

contents.text: This document specifies an IP-based encapsulation for MPLS, called MPLS-in-UDP for situations where UDP (User Datagram Protocol) encapsulation is preferred to direct use of MPLS, e.g., to enable UDP-based ECMP (Equal-Cost Multipath) or link aggregation. The MPLS-in-UDP encapsulation technology must only be deployed within a single network (with a single network operator) or networks of an adjacent set of cooperating network operators where traffic is managed to avoid congestion, rather than over the Internet where congestion control is required. Usage restrictions apply to MPLS-in-UDP usage for traffic that is not congestion controlled and to UDP zero checksum usage with IPv6.
contents.ja: この文書では、UDPベースのECMP（等価コストマルチパス）またはを有効にするために、MPLS-で-UDP UDP（ユーザデータグラムプロトコル）カプセル化は、MPLSを直接使用することが好ましい状況で、例えばのためと呼ばれる、MPLSのためのIPベースのカプセル化を指定しますリンクアグリゲーション。輻輳制御がどこにあるMPLS-で-UDPカプセル化技術は、のみ（単一のネットワーク・オペレータとの）単一のネットワーク内またはトラフィックが混雑を避けるために管理されている協力ネットワーク事業者の隣接セットのネットワークではなく、インターネット上で展開する必要があります必須。使用制限は、輻輳制御とIPv6でUDPチェックサムゼロの使用状況にはないトラフィックのためのMPLS-で-UDPの使用に適用されます。

1. Introduction
contents.ja: 1.はじめに

contents.text: This document specifies an IP-based encapsulation for MPLS, i.e., MPLS-in-UDP, which is applicable in some circumstances where IP-based encapsulation for MPLS is required and further fine-grained load balancing of MPLS packets over IP networks over Equal-Cost Multipath (ECMP) and/or Link Aggregation Groups (LAGs) is required as well. There are already IP-based encapsulations for MPLS that allow for fine-grained load balancing by using some special field in the encapsulation header as an entropy field. However, MPLS-in-UDP can be advantageous since networks have used the UDP port number fields as a basis for load-balancing solutions for some time.
contents.ja: この文書ではすなわち、MPLSのためのIPベースのカプセル化を指定し、MPLS-で-UDPいくつかのMPLSのためのIPベースのカプセル化が必要とされる状況とイコールオーバーIPネットワーク上でMPLSパケットのさらにきめ細かな負荷分散に適用可能であり、コストマルチパス（ECMP）、および/またはリンクアグリゲーショングループ（LAGの）も必要です。エントロピーフィールドとしてカプセル化ヘッダーにいくつかの特別なフィールドを使用することにより、きめ細かい負荷分散を可能にMPLSのためのIPベースのカプセル化はすでにあります。ネットワークはいくつかの時間のための負荷分散ソリューションの基礎としてUDPポート番号フィールドを使用しているので、MPLS-で-UDPは有利でありうる。

contents.text: Like other IP-based encapsulation methods for MPLS, this encapsulation allows for two Label Switching Routers (LSR) to be adjacent on a Label Switched Path (LSP), while separated by an IP network. In order to support this encapsulation, each LSR needs to know the capability to decapsulate MPLS-in-UDP by the remote LSRs. This specification defines only the data-plane encapsulation and does not concern itself with how the knowledge to use this encapsulation is conveyed. Specifically, this capability can be either manually configured on each LSR or dynamically advertised in manners that are outside the scope of this document.
contents.ja: MPLSのための他のIPベースのカプセル化方法のように、このカプセル化は、IPネットワークによって分離しながら、ラベルスイッチパス（LSP）に隣接される2つのラベルスイッチングルータ（LSR）を可能にします。このカプセル化をサポートするために、各LSRは、リモートのLSRでMPLS-で-UDPをデカプセル化する機能を知っている必要があります。この仕様は、データプレーンカプセル化を定義し、このカプセル化を使用するための知識を搬送する方法で自身に関係しません。具体的には、この機能は、手動で各LSRに設定することができ、又は動的に、この文書の範囲外である方法でアドバタイズ。

contents.text: Similarly, the MPLS-in-UDP encapsulation format defined in this document by itself cannot ensure the integrity and privacy of data packets being transported through the MPLS-in-UDP tunnels and cannot enable the tunnel decapsulators to authenticate the tunnel encapsulator. Therefore, in the case where any of the above security issues is concerned, the MPLS-in-UDP SHOULD be secured with IPsec [RFC4301] or Datagram Transport Layer Security (DTLS) [RFC6347]. For more details, please see Section 6 (Security Considerations).
contents.ja: 同様に、それ自体で本文書で定義されたMPLS-で-UDPカプセル化フォーマットは、MPLS-で-UDPトンネルを通って搬送されているデータパケットの完全性およびプライバシーを確​​保できず、トンネルカプセル化を認証するために、トンネルdecapsulatorsを有効にすることができません。したがって、上記のセキュリティ問題のいずれかが懸念される場合には、MPLS-UDPでは、IPsec [RFC4301]またはデータグラムトランスポート層セキュリティ（DTLS）[RFC6347]で固定されてください。詳細については、第6章（セキュリティ上の考慮事項）を参照してください。

contents.text: 1.1. Existing Encapsulations
contents.ja: 1.1。既存のカプセル化

contents.text: Currently, there are several IP-based encapsulations for MPLS such as MPLS-in-IP, MPLS-in-GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation) [RFC4023], and MPLS-in-L2TPv3 (Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol Version 3) [RFC4817]. In all these methods, the IP addresses can be varied to achieve load balancing.
contents.ja: 現在、いくつかのIPベースのようなMPLS-で-IP、MPLSインGRE（総称ルーティングカプセル化）[RFC4023]としてMPLSのためのカプセル化、およびMPLSインのL2TPv3がある（レイヤ2トンネリングプロトコルバージョン3）[RFC4817] 。すべてのこれらの方法では、IPアドレスは、負荷分散を達成するために変更することができます。

contents.text: All these IP-based encapsulations for MPLS are specified for both IPv4 and IPv6. In the case of IPv6-based encapsulations, the IPv6 Flow Label can be used for ECMP and LAGs [RFC6438]. However, there is no such entropy field in the IPv4 header.
contents.ja: MPLSのためのこれらのすべてのIPベースのカプセル化は、IPv4とIPv6の両方に指定されています。 IPv6ベースのカプセル化の場合には、IPv6のフローラベルは、ECMPとのLAG [RFC6438]のために使用することができます。しかし、IPv4ヘッダには、このようなエントロピーフィールドは存在しません。

contents.text: For MPLS-in-GRE as well as MPLS-in-L2TPv3, protocol fields (the GRE Key and the L2TPv3 Session ID, respectively) can be used as the load-balancing key as described in [RFC5640]. For this, intermediate routers need to understand these fields in the context of being used as load-balancing keys.
contents.ja: MPLSインGREのために、並びにMPLSインのL2TPv3、プロトコルフィールド（GREキーとそれぞれのL2TPv3セッションIDは、）[RFC5640]で説明されるように負荷分散キーとして使用することができます。このため、中間ルータは、負荷分散キーとして使用されているのコンテキストでこれらのフィールドを理解する必要があります。

contents.text: 1.2. Motivations for MPLS-in-UDP Encapsulation
contents.ja: 1.2。 MPLS-で-UDPカプセル化のための動機

contents.text: Most existing routers in IP networks are already capable of distributing IP traffic "microflows" [RFC2474] over ECMPs and/or LAG based on the hash of the five-tuple of UDP [RFC768] and TCP packets (i.e., source IP address, destination IP address, source port, destination port, and protocol). By encapsulating the MPLS packets into a UDP tunnel and using the source port of the UDP header as an entropy field, the existing load-balancing capability as mentioned above can be leveraged to provide fine-grained load balancing of MPLS traffic over IP networks.
contents.ja: IPネットワーク内のほとんどの既存のルータは、UDP [RFC768]とTCPパケットの5タプル（すなわち、送信元IPアドレス、送信先のハッシュに基づいてECMPsおよび/またはLAGの上に[RFC2474]すでにIPトラフィック「マイクロフロー」を配布することができますIPアドレス、送信元ポート、宛先ポート、およびプロトコル）。 UDPトンネルにMPLSパケットをカプセル化し、エントロピーフィールドとUDPヘッダの送信元ポートを使用することにより、上述したように、既存の負荷分散機能は、IPネットワーク上のMPLSトラフィックのきめ細かな負荷分散を提供するために活用することができます。

contents.text: 1.3. Applicability Statements
contents.ja: 1.3。適用性ステートメント

contents.text: The MPLS-in-UDP encapsulation technology MUST only be deployed within a single network (with a single network operator) or networks of an adjacent set of cooperating network operators where traffic is managed to avoid congestion, rather than over the Internet where congestion control is required. Furthermore, packet filters SHOULD be added to prevent MPLS-in-UDP packets from escaping from the network due to misconfiguration or packet errors.
contents.ja: 輻輳制御がどこにあるMPLS-で-UDPカプセル化技術は、のみ（単一のネットワーク・オペレータとの）単一のネットワーク内またはトラフィックが混雑を避けるために管理されている協力ネットワーク事業者の隣接セットのネットワークではなく、インターネット上で展開する必要があります必須。さらに、パケットフィルタは、設定ミスやパケットエラーによるネットワークから逃げるMPLS-で-UDPパケットを防ぐために添加されるべきです。

contents.text: This field contains a 16-bit entropy value that is generated by the encapsulator to uniquely identify a flow. What constitutes a flow is locally determined by the encapsulator and therefore is outside the scope of this document. What algorithm is actually used by the encapsulator to generate an entropy value is outside the scope of this document.

contents.text: A major motivation for encapsulating MPLS in UDP is to improve the use of multipath (such as ECMP) in cases where traffic is to traverse routers that are able to hash on UDP Port and IP address. As such, in many cases this may reduce the occurrence of congestion and improve usage of available network capacity. However, it is also necessary to ensure that the network, including applications that use the network, responds appropriately in more difficult cases, such as when link or equipment failures have reduced the available capacity.

As specified in [RFC5405]:

Consequently, a tunnel carrying IP-based traffic should already interact appropriately with other traffic sharing the path, and specific congestion control mechanisms for the tunnel are not necessary.

contents.text: For this reason, where MPLS-in-UDP tunneling is used to carry IP traffic that is known to be congestion controlled, the UDP tunnels MAY be used within a single network or across multiple networks, with cooperating network operators. Internet IP traffic is generally assumed to be congestion controlled. Similarly, in general, Layer 3 VPNs are carrying IP traffic that is similarly assumed to be congestion controlled.

contents.text: However, MPLS is also used in many cases to carry traffic that is not necessarily congestion controlled. For example, MPLS may be used to carry pseudowire or VPN traffic where specific bandwidth guarantees are provided to each pseudowire or to each VPN.

contents.text: 6. Security Considerations
contents.ja: 6.セキュリティの考慮事項

contents.text: The security problems faced with the MPLS-in-UDP tunnel are exactly the same as those faced with MPLS-in-IP and MPLS-in-GRE tunnels [RFC4023]. In other words, the MPLS-in-UDP tunnel as defined in this document by itself cannot ensure the integrity and privacy of data packets being transported through the MPLS-in-UDP tunnel and cannot enable the tunnel decapsulator to authenticate the tunnel encapsulator. In the case where any of the above security issues is concerned, the MPLS-in-UDP tunnel SHOULD be secured with IPsec or DTLS. IPsec was designed as a network security mechanism, and therefore it resides at the network layer. As such, if the tunnel is secured with IPsec, the UDP header would not be visible to intermediate routers anymore in either IPsec tunnel or transport mode. As a result, the meaning of adopting the MPLS-in-UDP tunnel as an alternative to the MPLS-in-GRE or MPLS-in-IP tunnel is lost. By comparison, DTLS is better suited for application security and can better preserve network- and transport-layer protocol information. Specifically, if DTLS is used, the destination port of the UDP header MUST be set to an IANA-assigned value (6636) indicating MPLS-in-UDP with DTLS, and that UDP port MUST NOT be used for other traffic. The UDP source port field can still be used to add entropy, e.g., for load-sharing purposes. DTLS usage is limited to a single DTLS session for any specific tunnel encapsulator/decapsulator pair (identified by source and destination IP addresses). Both IP addresses MUST be unicast addresses -- multicast traffic is not supported when DTLS is used. An MPLS-in-UDP tunnel decapsulator implementation that supports DTLS is expected to be able to establish DTLS sessions with multiple tunnel encapsulators. Likewise, an MPLS-in-UDP tunnel encapsulator implementation is expected to be able to establish DTLS sessions with multiple decapsulators. (However, different source and/or destination IP addresses may be involved. See Section 3.1 for discussion of one situation where use of different source IP addresses is important.)

contents.text: If the tunnel is not secured with IPsec or DTLS, some other method should be used to ensure that packets are decapsulated and forwarded by the tunnel tail only if those packets were encapsulated by the tunnel head. If the tunnel lies entirely within a single administrative domain, address filtering at the boundaries can be used to ensure that no packet with the IP source address of a tunnel endpoint or with the IP destination address of a tunnel endpoint can enter the domain from outside. However, when the tunnel head and the tunnel tail are not in the same administrative domain, this may become difficult, and filtering based on the destination address can even become impossible if the packets must traverse the public Internet. Sometimes only source address filtering (but not destination address filtering) is done at the boundaries of an administrative domain. If this is the case, the filtering does not provide effective protection at all unless the decapsulator of an MPLS-in-UDP validates the IP source address of the packet.

contents.text: This document does not require that the decapsulator validate the IP source address of the tunneled packets (with the exception that the IPv6 source address MUST be validated when UDP zero-checksum mode is used with IPv6), but it should be understood that failure to do so presupposes that there is effective destination-based (or a combination of source-based and destination-based) filtering at the boundaries. MPLS-based VPN services rely on a VPN label in the MPLS label stack to identify the VPN. Corruption of that label could leak traffic across VPN boundaries. Such leakage is highly undesirable when inter-VPN isolation is used for privacy or security reasons. When that is the case, UDP checksums SHOULD be used for MPLS-in-UDP with both IPv4 and IPv6, and in particular, UDP zero-checksum mode SHOULD NOT be used with IPv6. Each UDP checksum covers the VPN label, thereby providing increased assurance of isolation among VPNs.
